Vairimorpha ceranae is a microsporidian parasite that infects the European honey bee (Apis mellifera). It is a single-celled, spore-forming organism that belongs to the phylum Microsporidia.

Vairimorpha ceranae is an obligate intracellular parasite, meaning it can only replicate and propagate within the host cells of its honey bee host. The parasite primarily infects the epithelial cells of the honey bee's midgut, where it undergoes a complex life cycle involving multiple developmental stages.

The infective stage of V. ceranae is the spore, which is relatively small (around 3-4 microns in diameter) and can be transmitted to honey bees through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. Once inside the host, the spore germinates and releases its sporoplasm, which then invades the midgut epithelial cells.

Within the host cells, the parasite undergoes a series of developmental stages, including merogony (multiplication of the parasite), sporogony (formation of new spores), and the eventual release of the mature spores, which can then infect other host cells or be transmitted to other honey bees.

Vairimorpha ceranae is of particular interest in the field of apiculture due to its potential role in the decline of honey bee populations worldwide. The infection of honey bees by this parasite has been associated with increased colony mortality, reduced lifespan of individual bees, and potential disruptions to the overall health and functioning of honey bee colonies.
